tn.text: Jeremiah has just been praying to Yahweh.

tn.ref: Send them out from before me, for them to go away
tn.text: "Send them away from me! Let them go forth!" He repeats this idea for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
AT: "The people whom God said must die" or "the ones certain to die"
Yahweh has just told them he will send some of them to death, some to die by the sword, some to die by famine, and some to be captives.
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|1:8]].

tn.ref: I will make of them a horrifying thing to all the kingdoms of the earth, because of what Manasseh son of Hezekiah, king of Judah, did in Jerusalem
tn.text: AT: "And I will make them a frightful thing to all the kingdoms of the earth because of what Manasseh the son of Hezekiah, king of Judah, did in Jerusalem." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: I will assign them to four groups
tn.text: AT: "I will appoint four groups over them"
Yahweh has just told them he will assign them to four groups to kill them—the sword, dogs, birds, and beasts.

tn.ref: For who will have compassion for you, Jerusalem? Who will grieve for you? Who will turn to ask about your welfare?
tn.text: AT: "No one should have compassion on you, the people who live in Jerusalem. No one should mourn for your destruction. No one should ask why you became such a miserable people." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: You have forsaken me ... you have gone back from me
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the people have, indeed, forsaken Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
a farm tool with a long handle and sharp metal prongs, used especially for lifting and tossing grain in the air for winnowing.
"I will cause their children to die" or "I will let their enemies kill their children"
Yahweh has just told them no one will care about them and that he will destroy his people since they would not turn from their wicked ways.
women whose husbands have died

tn.ref: more than the sands of the seashore
tn.text: AT: "more than you can count" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"happen to them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: She will be ashamed and embarrassed
tn.text: The words "ashamed" and "embarrassed" mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of shame. AT: "She will be completely ashamed." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
In these verse, Jeremiah speaks to Yahweh about his suffering, and Yahweh answers him.
Jeremiah pretends to speak to his mother as a way to emphasize how sad he is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])

tn.ref: a man of controversy and argument
tn.text: The words "controversy" and "argument" mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize how much Jeremiah is arguing. AT: "a man with whom everyone argues all the time." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
to give a loan to someone

tn.ref: Will I not rescue you for good?
tn.text: The implicit answer to this question is "yes". AT: "I will certainly rescue you for good!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Those are the enemies of Jeremiah who disagreed with his prophecies.

tn.ref: in the time of calamity and distress
tn.text: Here the words "calamity" and "distress" mean basically the same thing. They emphasize the amount or intensity of the calamity. AT: "in the time of great calamity." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

The implied answer is "no". Also, the iron represents the firmness of God's judgment. AT: "My judgment cannot be broken, just like iron cannot be smashed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Especially iron from the north that is mixed with bronze?
tn.text: This second question makes the first even stronger, and uses extra strong iron in the metaphor. AT: "Even more, my judgment is like super strong iron" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
In these verse, Yahweh speaks to the nation of Israel as if it were one person.
The words "wealth" and "treasures" mean the same thing and refer to anything that people consider to be valuable. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
things that you steal from a city after conquering it

tn.ref: a land that you do not know
tn.text: "to a land that is strange to you"

tn.ref: for a fire will ignite, kindled in my wrath against you
tn.text: The wrath of God is spoken of as if it were a destructive fire. AT: "I will destroy you because I am very angry with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Jeremiah speaks to Yahweh.
AT: "Remember me" or "Consider me and my situation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"those who search after me to harm me"

tn.ref: In your patience do not take me away.
tn.text: AT: "Please do not continue to be patient with them and do not allow me to die now."
AT: "I have heard your message." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"I understood your message"

tn.ref: your name is proclaimed on me
tn.text: "people identified me as one who belongs to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I did not sit in the circle of
tn.text: AT: "I did not spend time with" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Why is my pain ongoing and my wound incurable, refusing to be healed?
tn.text: AT: "My pain is ongoing and my wound incurable. I cannot be healed." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Will you be like deceitful waters to me, waters that dry up?
tn.text: AT: "Your promises to me are like a stream I go to for a drink only to find it dried up?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: you will be like my mouth
tn.text: Jeremiah is compared to the mouth of Yahweh because he will be used to speak Yahweh's message. AT: "you will speak for me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
The pronoun, "yourself", is used here to emphasis the command was specifically for Jeremiah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])

tn.ref: like an impenetrable bronze wall to this people
tn.text: Yahweh compares Jeremiah to a wall because the people will not be able to defeat him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]]

tn.ref: they will wage war against you. But they will not defeat you
tn.text: AT: "They will fight against you, but they will not defeat you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The words "save" and "rescue" mean the same thing and emphasize the safety that God promises. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|1:8]].

tn.ref: rescue you from ... and redeem you from
tn.text: These phrases have similar meanings and are used together to emphasize the safety that God provides. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
a ruler who demands absolute obedience and is not friendly for the people under his rule
